body.p:
To His Excellency Thos. E. Bramlette
Governor of Ky

The undersigned union men and neighbors of Mathew McCallister, beg leave to represent to your Excellency that they have known him from his youth up to the present time, and that he has always borne a good character, as a sober, industrious, and peaceable man, never having a difficulty with any man up to the time Minor Horton provoked the altircation in Augst 1862 for which assault he was fined Two Hundred ^fifty^ Dollars, during the last term of the Trimble County Circuit Court which fine we pray your Excellency to remit.

Mathew McCallister has always been and is now an unflinching Union man, and he as suffered much by having his property taken by the rebels and for which he was insulted (in part) by said Horton, who was a rabid rebel, and a few days after the difficulty he left his family and joined the rebel army, under Gen H Marshall, and remained some six or eight months; after which he returned home for avowed purpose of recruiting for the Southern Army. Finding it a slow business he concluded to take the oath, and become a galvanized Union man, with all his rebel proclivities clinging to him.

We further state, the the witnesses, who have signed sd McCallister's affidavit, and who were present, when the altercation took place at the meeting house are all men of undoubted veracity & honor viz; Rot A Wright J T Simmons Alfred Staten. William S Brent T. P. Jones & E. P. Campbell
